message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cholera toxin indeed ADP-ribosylates Gs and keeps adenylate cyclase active, which increases the level of intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). The other options are incorrect: Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2; Botulinum toxin cleaves synaptobrevin, blocking vesicle formation and the release of the excitatory neurotransmitter acetylcholine; Anthrax toxin also inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of EF-2.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cholera toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating Gs and increasing cAMP levels, leading to secretion of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestines. Diphtheria toxin cleaves elongation factor 2 and inhibits protein synthesis. Botulinum toxin cleaves SNAP-25, blocking vesicle formation and the release of acetylcholine. Anthrax toxin produces edema factor and lethal factor, both of which disrupt cellular signaling pathways but do not ADP-ribosylate elongation factor 2. Therefore, the correct pair is (B) Cholera toxin - ADP-ribosylates Gs, keeping adenylate cyclase active and ↑ [cAMP].

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cholera toxin ADP-ribosylates Gs, leading to increased cAMP levels, which in turn leads to fluid secretion in the intestines. Diphtheria toxin cleaves elongation factor-2 (EF-2), preventing protein synthesis. Botulinum toxin cleaves synaptobrevin, blocking the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, leading to muscle paralysis. Anthrax toxin can edema factor, lethal factor, and protective antigen, which can cause tissue destruction, immune suppression, and cell death, respectively. Therefore, the correct match is (B) Cholera toxin - ADP-ribosylates Gs, keeping adenylate cyclase active and ↑ [cAMP].

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cholera toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating Gs, which keeps adenylate cyclase active and increases [cAMP]. Diphtheria toxin and botulinum toxin both cleave synaptobrevin, but diphtheria toxin blocks protein synthesis while botulinum toxin blocks the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine. Anthrax toxin ADP-ribosylates elongation factor-2 (EF-2) and inhibits protein synthesis, but it is not matched with cholera toxin. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cholera toxin binds to and activates G proteins in intestinal cells, leading to the production of cAMP and subsequent loss of electrolytes and fluid into the lumen, causing diarrhea. Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2). Botulinum toxin cleaves proteins involved in vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release, leading to muscle paralysis. Anthrax toxin has three components, with one component ADP-ribosylating EF-2, inhibiting protein synthesis. Therefore, the correct match is (B) Cholera toxin - ADP-ribosylates Gs, keeping adenylate cyclase active and ↑ [cAMP].

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The mechanisms of action listed for each exotoxin are accurate. Among the options, Cholera toxin ADP-ribosylates Gs, which keeps adenylate cyclase active and increases [cAMP].

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Cholera toxin ADP-ribosylates Gs, which keeps adenylate cyclase active and increases cAMP levels. Diphtheria toxin cleaves elongation factor-2, Botulinum toxin cleaves synaptobrevin, and Anthrax toxin ADP-ribosylates EF-2 and inhibits protein synthesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cholera toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating Gs and increasing cAMP levels, leading to diarrhea. Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating EF-2, Botulinum toxin blocks the release of acetylcholine and Anthrax toxin also inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating EF-2. Therefore, the correct pair is Cholera toxin - ADP-ribosylates Gs, keeping adenylate cyclase active and ↑ [cAMP].

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cholera toxin does ADP-ribosylation of Gs protein, which keeps adenylate cyclase active and increases cyclic AMP concentration. Diphtheria toxin cleaves elongation factor 2 (EF-2), inhibiting protein synthesis. Botulinum toxin blocks vesicle formation and releases the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine. Anthrax toxin does a tripartite action of disrupting host cell signaling, causing edema factor-mediated fluid buildup, and interfering with host immune function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only cholera toxin ADP-ribosylates Gs, keeping adenylate cyclase active and increasing [cAMP]. Diphtheria toxin cleaves elongation factor 2. Botulinum toxin cleaves synaptosomal-associated protein 25 (SNAP-25) and inhibits release of acetylcholine. Anthrax toxin consists of three proteins, including protective antigen, which binds to host cell receptors and forms a pore that allows entry of edema factor and lethal factor. Lethal factor cleaves mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase (MAPKK) and inhibits immune system function.
